Title:
Phylogenetic analysis of reproductive traits of maniraptoran
theropods and its implications for egg parataxonomy.
Keywords:
Maniraptora; Theropoda; birds; egg; eggshell;
parataxonomy.; reproduction
Abstract:
A phylogenetic analysis of reporoductive and oological
(egg) traits of theropod taxa allows determination of the sequence in
which these traits evolved in Theropoda. Our results indicate that
several avian reproductive traits, such as adults sitting on eggs,
asymetrical eggs, unornamented eggshell surface, and complex eggshell
ultrastructure, were already prsent in non-avian maniraptorans, and
could have evolved in more basal theropods. In addition, non-avian
maniraptorans laid two eggs at a time and oriented their eggs
subvertically or subhorizontally in their nests, features not retained
by neornithine birds. Based on our cladistic analysis it is also
possible to infer the phylogenetic affinity of ootaxa of unknown
parentage: Protoceratopsidovum was laid by a maniraptoran more derived
than oviraptorids, and Parvoolithus probably belonged to a Cretaceous
bird. Finally, our analysis reveals that many of the hgih-level
categories of egg parataxonomy (morphotypes and basic types) are
unnatural groupings (i.e. non-monophyletic). We recommend that these
high-level categories be abandoned because oofamilies are sufficient to
categorize egg taxa.
